messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 48 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Regret Minimization and Convergence to Equilibria in General-sum Markov Games

Paper Abstract: Abstract An abundance of recent impossibility results establish that regret minimization in Markov games with adversarial opponents is both statistically and computationally intractable. Nevertheless, none of these results preclude the possibility of regret minimization under the assumption that all parties adopt the same learning procedure. In this work, we present the first (to our knowledge) algorithm for learning in general-sum Markov games that provides sublinear regret guarantees when executed by all agents. The bounds we obtain are for swap regret, and thus, along the way, imply convergence to a correlated equilibrium. Our algorithm is decentralized, computationally efficient, and does not require any communication between agents. Our key observation is that online learning via policy optimization in Markov games essentially reduces to a form of weighted regret minimization, with unknown weights determined by the path length of the agents‚Äô policy sequence. Consequently, controlling the path length leads to weighted regret objectives for which sufficiently adaptive algorithms provide sublinear regret guarantees.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 48 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 48"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "A natural actor-critic framework for zero-sum markov games",
        "Faster no-regret learning dynamics for extensive-form correlated and coarse correlated equilibria",
        "Uncoupled learning dynamics with O‚Äã(log‚Å°T)ùëÇùëáO(\\log T) swap regret in multiplayer games",
        "Near-optimal reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "From external to internal regret",
        "R-max-a general polynomial time algorithm for near-optimal reinforcement learning",
        "A comprehensive survey of multiagent reinforcement learning",
        "Provably efficient exploration in policy optimization",
        "Fast policy extragradient methods for competitive games with entropy regularization",
        "Hedging in games: Faster convergence of external and swap regrets",
        "Settling the complexity of computing two-player nash equilibria",
        "Unifying pac and regret: Uniform pac bounds for episodic reinforcement learning",
        "The complexity of computing a nash equilibrium",
        "Independent policy gradient methods for competitive reinforcement learning",
        "Near-optimal no-regret learning in general games",
        "The complexity of markov equilibrium in stochastic games",
        "Near-optimal no-regret learning for general convex games",
        "Kernelized multiplicative weights for 0/1-polyhedral games: Bridging the gap between learning in extensive-form and normal-form games",
        "Learning in games: Robustness of fast convergence",
        "Strategy iteration is strongly polynomial for 2-player turn-based stochastic games with a constant discount factor",
        "Efficient learning algorithms for changing environments",
        "Nash q-learning for general-sum stochastic games",
        "V-learning‚Äìa simple, efficient, decentralized algorithm for multiagent RL",
        "Simultaneously learning stochastic and adversarial episodic mdps with known transition",
        "A closer look at small-loss bounds for bandits with graph feedback",
        "Markov games as a framework for multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Friend-or-foe q-learning in general-sum games",
        "A sharp analysis of model-based reinforcement learning with self-play",
        "Learning markov games with adversarial opponents: Efficient algorithms and fundamental limits",
        "Provably efficient reinforcement learning in decentralized general-sum markov games",
        "On improving model-free algorithms for decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning",
        "Optimal no-regret learning in general games: Bounded regret with unbounded step-sizes via clairvoyant MWU",
        "Optimization, learning, and games with predictable sequences",
        "Optimistic policy optimization with bandit feedback",
        "Stochastic games",
        "Solving discounted stochastic two-player games with near-optimal time and sample complexity",
        "When can we learn general-sum markov games with a large number of players sample-efficiently?",
        "Fast convergence of regularized learning in games",
        "Online learning in unknown markov games",
        "More adaptive algorithms for adversarial bandits",
        "Online reinforcement learning in stochastic games",
        "Last-iterate convergence of decentralized optimistic gradient descent/ascent in infinite-horizon competitive markov games",
        "Learning zero-sum simultaneous-move markov games using function approximation and correlated equilibrium",
        "Decentralized optimistic hyperpolicy mirror descent: Provably no-regret learning in markov games",
        "Model-based multi-agent RL in zero-sum markov games with near-optimal sample complexity",
        "Multi-agent reinforcement learning: A selective overview of theories and algorithms",
        "Policy optimization for markov games: Unified framework and faster convergence",
        "Provably efficient policy optimization for two-player zero-sum markov games"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 48 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Regret Minimization and Convergence to Equilibria in General-sum Markov Games, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
